column1: Oeyvind was his name. A low barren cliff overhung the house in which he was born
column2: fir and birch looked down on the roof
column3: and wild-cherry strewed flowers over it. Upon this roof there walked about a little goat
column4: which belonged to Oeyvind. He was kept there that he might not go astray
column5: and Oeyvind carried leaves and grass up to him. One fine day the goat leaped down
column6: and—away to the cliff; he went straight up
column7: and came where he never had been before. Oeyvind did not see him when he came out after dinner
column8: and thought immediately of the fox. He grew hot all over

column13: this goat?" she asked.Oeyvind stood with eyes and mouth wide open
